info.title: PlantEye API
info.description:
This is a REST API made for distributors, integrators and customers to make it easier to use the system in custom environments!
It provides access to system internals, such as network settings, that commonly need to be changed, without exposing too much.

The whole documentation has been written according to OpenAPI 3 specification and can be downloaded above to be integrated into other REST or API frameworks, such as Postman.

tags.name: Device
tags.description: Gives direct access to the hardware

tags.name: Settings
tags.description: Modify settings related to the scanner itself as well as properties of the scans

tags.name: Logs
tags.description: Direct access to process and system logs to help with troubleshooting

tags.name: Scan
tags.description: For starting, stopping and identifying scans

tags.name: Services
tags.description: Troubleshooting facility that can be used to check if processes are running

tags.name: Info
tags.description: Quick access to some system information

DigestAuthIntegration.description: Digest Authentication that gives access to additional functions that end users should not be able to access.

DigestAuthPhenospex.description: Digest Authentication that gives full access to all functions and removes restrictions for certain filter options.

get.description: Returns the serial number of the device if it has been set.

put.description: Sets the numerical serial number of the PlantEye.

requestBody.description: New serial must only contain digits, but leading 0s are fine.

Not a number.value: 400 Bad Request (abc is not a number)

post.description: Sets the numerical serial number of the PlantEye.

requestBody.description: New serial must only contain digits, but leading 0s are fine.

Not a number.value: 400 Bad Request (abc is not a number)

get.description: Use the [POST method](#operation/DeviceReboot) instead

post.description: Reboots the system 5 seconds after this call has been made, as long as there is no network restart in progress.

Default.value: System is going down for reboot in 5 seconds.

get.description: Use the [POST method](#operation/DeviceShutdown) instead

post.description: Shuts down the system 5 seconds after this call has been made, as long as there is no network restart in progress.

Default.value: System is shutting down in 5 seconds.

get.description: Returns the last response from the microcontroller if it exists.

post.description:
Sends a command to the microcontroller via the scanner service. Then waits for 50ms and returns the last response, if it exists.
Note: Use at your own risk, improper use of some commands can cause serious damage to the device.

requestBody.description: Command to send to the microcontroller. You can request a list of valid commands from Phenospex, or look at the [list of supported commands](http://intranet/wiki/doku.php?id=planteye_data_flow) in the internal Phenospex wiki.

Default.value: 503 No response from MCU (is the scanner service running?)

get.description: Returns the current contents of `/etc/network/interfaces`.

PlantEye.value:
# This file describes the network interfaces available on your system
# and how to activate them. For more information, see interfaces(5).

source /etc/network/interfaces.d/*

# The loopback network interface
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

# The primary network interface
allow-hotplug enp1s0
#iface enp1s0 inet dhcp
iface enp1s0 inet static
        address 192.168.3.121
        netmask 255.255.252.0
        gateway 192.168.1.254
        #dns-nameservers 192.168.1.1

#allow-hotplug ens3
#iface ens3 inet dhcp

put.description: Replaces the current contents of `/etc/network/interfaces` with the request body.

post.description: Replaces the current contents of `/etc/network/interfaces` with the request body. Uses the form field `interfaces-file`.

get.description: Returns a list of all currently available external IP addresses of the system. Or an empty list if no interface is up.
Returns a list of all available interfaces of the system. Or an empty list if no interface is up.

Minimalistic page that can be used to update settings in the file `/etc/network/interfaces`. See the [set interface endpoint](#operation/NetworkInterfaceKey) to get a list of settings that can be updated and what they are for. Note that changing these settings by themselves won't restart the network. There is a separate [endpoint to restart the network](#operation/NetworkChange).

Page.value:
Edit Network Settings

Interface:

Key:

post.description: Once you are done changing the settings of `/etc/network/interfaces` using the various endpoints, the network has to be restarted. This endpoint will restart the default network interface. After the restart you have 60 seconds to confirm that you can still reach the server with [the confirm endpoint](#operation/NetworkConfirm). If you cannot confirm in time that the webserver is reachable, then it will revert to the previous working settings and restart the interfaces again.

parameters.name: Request-Timeout
parameters.description: Optional timeout in seconds before network settings will be reverted.

Location.description: Endpoint for redirect. It tries to parse `/etc/network/interfaces`, find the address for the default interface and use it instead of `<new_ip>` in the example. If it can't find an address, e.g. because the interface was set to DHCP, then it will use the literal string `<new_ip>`. In the latter case it is up to the user to find out what the new IP will be.

Redirect.value: 202 Network is going down for restart

Request-Timeout out of bounds.value: 400 Bad request (timeout must be between 1 and 3600 seconds)

get.description: Once you are done changing the settings of `/etc/network/interfaces` using the various endpoints, the network has to be restarted. This is done via the [restart network endpoint](#operation/NetworkChange). After the restart you have 20 seconds to confirm that you can still reach the server with this endpoint.

Access-Control-Allow-Origin.description: Since this endpoint will be redirected to during a network change, we need to allow Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS).

post.description: Once you are done changing the settings of `/etc/network/interfaces` using the various endpoints, the network has to be restarted. This is done via the [restart network endpoint](#operation/NetworkChange). After the restart you have 20 seconds to confirm that you can still reach the server with this endpoint.

Access-Control-Allow-Origin.description: Since this endpoint will be redirected to during a network change, we need to allow Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS).

get.description:
Returns a specific line from `/etc/network/interfaces`. If there was a change in this file, but no restart of the network via the [apply changes endpoint](#operation/NetworkChange), then the current values of the networking service and the values inside `/etc/network/interfaces` might differ. This endpoint only shows the current state of the file and what will be used at the time of a network restart.
Note: Exception to the rule is the key `ip` which will return the current IP assigned to the interface and might differ from `address` for the reasons mentioned above.

parameters.name: interface
parameters.description: An array of all acceptable interfaces is obtainable from [/device/network/interfaces](#operation/NetworkInterfaces).

parameters.name: key
parameters.description:
List of possible keys:
- ` ` (empty key): Returns all values for the interface
- `ip`: Returns the current IP
- `method`: static or dhcp
- `address`: Static IP address
- `netmask`: Returns the netmask
- `gateway`: Returns the gateway
- `dns-nameservers`: Space separated list of all DNS servers
- `post-up`: Returns the first post-up rule. Use an empty key to see everything.

Empty key.value:
iface enp1s0 inet static
address 192.168.3.121
netmask 255.255.252.0
gateway 192.168.1.254
dns-nameservers 192.168.1.1 8.8.8.8

put.description: Modify or add a specific line in `/etc/network/interfaces` with the value used in the request body. If there was a change in this file, but no restart of the network via the [apply changes endpoint](#operation/NetworkChange), then the current values of the networking service and the values inside `/etc/network/interfaces` might differ. This endpoint only modifies the current state of the file and what will be used at the time of a network restart.

requestBody.description: New value that will be used for the `key` specified in the path.

parameters.name: interface
parameters.description: An array of all acceptable interfaces is obtainable from [/device/network/interfaces](#operation/NetworkInterfaces).

parameters.name: key
parameters.description:
List of possible keys: - `method`: static or dhcp - `address`: IP address if the method is set to static - `netmask`: For setting the netmask - `gateway`: For setting the gateway - `dns-nameservers`: Space separated list of all DNS servers - `post-up`: Will always be appended. The only allowed commands for post-up rules are `ip route` additions.
Note: Sending an empty request body will delete all lines for the given key.

PlantEye.value:
# This file describes the network interfaces available on your system
# and how to activate them. For more information, see interfaces(5).

source /etc/network/interfaces.d/*

# The loopback network interface
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

# The primary network interface
allow-hotplug enp1s0
#iface enp1s0 inet dhcp
iface enp1s0 inet static
        address 192.168.3.121
        netmask 255.255.252.0
        gateway 192.168.1.254
        #dns-nameservers 192.168.1.1

#allow-hotplug ens3
#iface ens3 inet dhcp

post.description: Modify or add a specific line in `/etc/network/interfaces` with the value used in the request body. Uses the upload field `interfaces-file`. If there was a change in this file, but no restart of the network via the [apply changes endpoint](#operation/NetworkChange), then the current values of the networking service and the values inside `/etc/network/interfaces` might differ. This endpoint only modifies the current state of the file and what will be used at the time of a network restart.

requestBody.description: New value that will be used for the `key` specified in the path.

parameters.name: interface
parameters.description: An array of all acceptable interfaces is obtainable from [/device/network/interfaces](#operation/NetworkInterfaces).

parameters.name: key
parameters.description:
List of possible keys: - `method`: static or dhcp - `address`: IP address if the method is set to static - `netmask`: For setting the netmask - `gateway`: For setting the gateway - `dns-nameservers`: Space separated list of all DNS servers - `post-up`: Will always be appended. The only allowed commands for post-up rules are `ip route` additions.
Note: Sending a request body with an empty `content` field will delete all lines for the given key.

PlantEye.value:
# This file describes the network interfaces available on your system
# and how to activate them. For more information, see interfaces(5).

source /etc/network/interfaces.d/*

# The loopback network interface
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

# The primary network interface
allow-hotplug enp1s0
#iface enp1s0 inet dhcp
iface enp1s0 inet static
        address 192.168.3.121
        netmask 255.255.252.0
        gateway 192.168.1.254
        #dns-nameservers 192.168.1.1

#allow-hotplug ens3
#iface ens3 inet dhcp

post.description:
Warning: Restarts the default network interface without any checks for correctness. Can potentially leave the system in an unreachable state. If possible use the [apply settings endpoint](#operation/NetworkChange).
Note: This endpoint is meant to be called over serial port if the system is not reachable or if any potential backup file should be ignored. If a backup file exists at reboot it will be restored. To remove the backup file use the apply settings endpoint mentioned above.

Resets the network back to factory settings if it is supported by the system. These values can vary, but by default the settings are:
- Network interface method: `static`
- IP address: `192.168.3.250`
- Netmask: `255.255.252.0`
- Gateway `192.168.1.254`

Default.value: 500 File required for reset does not exist

get.description:
Returns a JSON of most settings that influence the behaviour of the scanner service.
Changes to these settings will be used after a [restart of the scanner service](#operation/ServicesRestart).

put.description: Upload a new scanner configuration. Since some of the values have been set during calibration this endpoint should not be used if you just want to update a few values.

requestBody.description: Content that will replace the entire f500.json

post.description: Upload a new scanner configuration. Since some of the values have been set during calibration this endpoint should not be used if you just want to update a few values.

requestBody.description: Content that will replace the entire f500.json

get.description: Query specific settings that influence the behaviour of the scanner service.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The specific path you want to access. An empty `path` is identical to [the endpoint above](#operation/SettingsScanner).

put.description:
Update specific settings that influence the behaviour of the scanner service.
Changes to these settings will be used after a [restart of the scanner service](#operation/ServicesRestart).

parameters.name: path
parameters.description:
The specific path you want to access. An empty `path` is identical to [the endpoint above](#operation/SettingsScanner). The following paths do not require authentication: - `/xz_profile/lower_int_threshold`: Noise threshold filter, increase in case of strong sunlight or reflective surfaces (Range: [3..9], Default: 5) - `/xz_profile/first_to_max_thres`: Duplicate laser line filter, `0.0` means take the first point of noise you can find, `1.0` means always take the brightest points, reducing it can marginally increase measurement accuracy (Range: [0.5..1.0], Default: 1.0) - `/xz_profile/ms_rgb_max_int`: Saturation level for the conversion from raw 16bit camera values to 8bit RGB colours. Lower values result in brighter RGB, but may cause the scans to look overexposed (Range: [600-3000], Default: 2200). - `/barcode_detection/read_bc_trials`: Number of attempts for physical barcode detection. Setting it to 0 will disable barcode detection. (Range: [0..30], Default: 20) - `/barcode_detection/zmin`: Minimum distance of a physical barcode to the scanner. Should only be changed if a table or the ground is causing issues. Must correct `zhist_divn` after changing. (Range: [400..1100], Default: 400) - `/barcode_detection/zmax`: Maximum distance of a physical barcode to the scanner. Should only be changed if a barcode is out of range. Must correct `zhist_divn` after changing. (Range: [700..1500], Default: 1100) - `/barcode_detection/zhist_divn`: Resolution of Hough transformation. Should be zmax - zmin. (Range: [300..1100], Default: 700) - `/trigger/trigger_mode`:

    `1010` starts scan if scanner enable signal is received (rising edge) and stops the scan when scanner enable signal goes low. Every `field_id_mode` is supported.

    `1020` starts scan if scanner enable signal is received (rising edge) and stops the scan when a physical barcode is detected. If the scanner enable signal goes down before the stop barcode is detected, the measurement is discarded. `field_id_mode` must be 1.

    `2020` starts scan when a physical start barcode is detected, stops the scan when stop barcode is detected. field_id_mode parameter must be 1.

    `30XX` scans are started and stopped by the detection of physical barcodes

    `3001` scan in ascending order only (e.g. barcodes 6 - 7 - 8 ...)

    `3010` scan in descending order only (e.g. barcodes 5 - 4 - 3 ...)

    `3011` scan in ascending AND descending order

- `/trigger/field_id_mode`:

    `0`: All scans get the ID 0

    `1`: Scans are identified by physical barcodes

    `2`: Scans are identified by IDs, which have been set with the [POST /scan/block-id endpoint](#operation/ScanBlockID) prior to the end of the scan.

- `/scan/field_y_length`: Defines the length of a scan and must be equal to the physical length of the field, i.e. the distance between the physical barcodes, or the distance between rising and falling edge in `1010` mode. - `/watchdog/ping_ip`: The connection LED on the back of the PlantEye will light up as long as the IP address or system here can be reached. Can be set to `localhost` if there are no other systems involved. - `/watchdog/raw_data_ttl`: Old scans will be deleted before the hard drive gets full. But you can also choose to automatically discard files above a certain age, e.g. 864000s = 10 days. (Default: 864000)

requestBody.description: New value that will be used at the specified `path`.

post.description:
Update specific settings that influence the behaviour of the scanner service.
Changes to these settings will be used after a [restart of the scanner service](#operation/ServicesRestart).

parameters.name: path
parameters.description:
The specific path you want to access. An empty `path` is identical to [the endpoint above](#operation/SettingsScanner). The following paths do not require authentication: - `/xz_profile/lower_int_threshold`: Noise threshold filter, increase in case of strong sunlight or reflective surfaces (Range: [3..9], Default: 5) - `/xz_profile/first_to_max_thres`: Duplicate laser line filter, `0.0` means take the first point of noise you can find, `1.0` means always take the brightest points, reducing it can marginally increase measurement accuracy (Range: [0.5..1.0], Default: 1.0) - `/xz_profile/ms_rgb_max_int`: Saturation level for the conversion from raw 16bit camera values to 8bit RGB colours. Lower values result in brighter RGB, but may cause the scans to look overexposed (Range: [600-3000], Default: 2200). - `/barcode_detection/read_bc_trials`: Number of attempts for physical barcode detection. Setting it to 0 will disable barcode detection. (Range: [0..30], Default: 20) - `/barcode_detection/zmin`: Minimum distance of a physical barcode to the scanner. Should only be changed if a table or the ground is causing issues. Must correct `zhist_divn` after changing. (Range: [400..1100], Default: 400) - `/barcode_detection/zmax`: Maximum distance of a physical barcode to the scanner. Should only be changed if a barcode is out of range. Must correct `zhist_divn` after changing. (Range: [700..1500], Default: 1100) - `/barcode_detection/zhist_divn`: Resolution of Hough transformation. Should be zmax - zmin. (Range: [300..1100], Default: 700) - `/trigger/trigger_mode`:

    `1010` starts scan if scanner enable signal is received (rising edge) and stops the scan when scanner enable signal goes low. Every `field_id_mode` is supported.

    `1020` starts scan if scanner enable signal is received (rising edge) and stops the scan when a physical barcode is detected. If the scanner enable signal goes down before the stop barcode is detected, the measurement is discarded. `field_id_mode` must be 1.

    `2020` starts scan when a physical start barcode is detected, stops the scan when stop barcode is detected. field_id_mode parameter must be 1.

    `30XX` scans are started and stopped by the detection of physical barcodes

    `3001` scan in ascending order only (e.g. barcodes 6 - 7 - 8 ...)

    `3010` scan in descending order only (e.g. barcodes 5 - 4 - 3 ...)

    `3011` scan in ascending AND descending order

- `/trigger/field_id_mode`:

    `0`: All scans get the ID 0

    `1`: Scans are identified by physical barcodes

    `2`: Scans are identified by IDs, which have been set with the [POST /scan/block-id endpoint](#operation/ScanBlockID) prior to the end of the scan.

- `/scan/field_y_length`: Defines the length of a scan and must be equal to the physical length of the field, i.e. the distance between the physical barcodes, or the distance between rising and falling edge in `1010` mode. - `/watchdog/ping_ip`: The connection LED on the back of the PlantEye will light up as long as the IP address or system here can be reached. Can be set to `localhost` if there are no other systems involved. - `/watchdog/raw_data_ttl`: Old scans will be deleted before the hard drive gets full. But you can also choose to automatically discard files above a certain age, e.g. 864000s = 10 days. (Default: 864000)

requestBody.description: New value that will be used at the specified `path`.

get.description: Minimalistic page that can be used to edit the scanner settings. Can be used be support to easily modify the internal settings. Will ask for authentication when using any of the submit buttons.
Returns a list of all block ID configuration files that are currently on the system.

Used to read out the specific settings that will be applied to a scan with a specific block ID once it goes through the PHENA processing chain in HortControl. Among other things, these settings are used to transform, segment, triangulate and split scans.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The specific block you want to check. The only allowed non-integer value is `default`, which refers to a read-only block.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The settings you want to get. An empty path refers to the entire file.

Out of bounds.value: 400 Block ID must be between 0 and 9999

put.description: Used to update specific settings that will be applied to a scan with a specific block ID once it goes through the PHENA processing chain in HortControl. Among other things, these settings are used to transform, segment, triangulate and split scans.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The specific block you want to update. The only allowed non-integer value is `default`, which refers to a read-only block that will require authentication.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The settings you want to update. An empty path refers to the entire file.

requestBody.description: New value that will be used at the specified `path`.

Out of bounds.value: 400 Block ID must be between 0 and 9999

post.description: Used to update specific settings that will be applied to a scan with a specific block ID once it goes through the PHENA processing chain in HortControl. Among other things, these settings are used to transform, segment, triangulate and split scans.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The specific block you want to update. The only allowed non-integer value is `default`, which refers to a read-only block that will require authentication.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The settings you want to update. An empty path refers to the entire file.

requestBody.description: New value that will be used at the specified `path`.

Out of bounds.value: 400 Block ID must be between 0 and 9999

get.description: Minimalistic page that can be used to edit the block settings.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The specific block you want to edit. The only allowed non-integer value is `default`, which refers to a read-only block, that will require authorisation.

Out of bounds.value: 400 Block ID must be between 0 and 9999

get.description: This returns the system logs of at least warning level for the services that were made by Phenospex. Requires systemd to be installed on the system.

Truncated version of [the endpoint above](#operation/Logs). This returns the last 50 lines of system logs of at least warning level for the services that were made by Phenospex. Requires systemd to be installed on the system.
This returns the system logs of at least warning level for a specific service. Requires systemd to be installed on the system.

parameters.name: service
parameters.description:
Specific service that you want the logs of.
Allowed services are any of the following:
- `f500` (the scanner itself)
- `webserver`
- `lighttpd`
- `chrony`
- `cron`
- `incron`

get.description: Truncated version of [the endpoint above](#operation/LogsService). This returns the last 50 lines of system logs of at least warning level for a specific service. Requires systemd to be installed on the system.

parameters.name: service
parameters.description: Specific service that you want the logs of.

get.description: This returns all system logs of at least warning level for all services. Requires systemd to be installed on the system.
Truncated version of [the endpoint above](#operation/LogsAll). This returns the last 50 lines of at least warning level for all services. Requires systemd to be installed on the system.
Not implemented

post.description: Not implemented

Tries to start a scan by sending a START signal to the hardware.
Note: Needs version 4 of microcontroller firmware and will only work on PlantEyes produced after January 2020. Due to software limitations there is no immediate return value that indicates whether the signal was sent successfully.

Tries to stop a scan by sending a STOP signal to the hardware.
Note: Needs version 4 of microcontroller firmware and will only work on PlantEyes produced after January 2020. Due to software limitations there is no immediate return value that indicates whether the signal was sent successfully.

get.description:
Returns the numerical ID that will be used to identify the next scan or `-1` if no ID has been specified.
These will only be used if the right field id mode is set, see [/settings/scanner/trigger/field_id_mode](#operation/SettingsScannerPath).

post.description:
Set a numerical ID that will be used to identify the next scan.
These will only be used if the right field id mode is set, see [/settings/scanner/trigger/field_id_mode](#operation/SettingsScannerPath).

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The next scan will get this number

schema.description: Will return the ID on success

Might be one of:
- Not a number: `400 Block ID is not a valid number (id: {id})`
- Out of range: `400 Block ID must be between 0 and 9999`
- Empty ID: `400 Empty ID`
- Otherwise: `400 Bad request`

Not a number.value: 400 Block ID is not a valid number (id: abc)

Out of range.value: 400 Block ID must be between 0 and 9999

get.description: An HTML page that can be used to look at 3D scans.
List of the last 3D scans that are still on the system.

Redirects to the [3D viewer page](#operation/ViewerIndex).
Note: Currently it does not automatically open the file.

parameters.name: file
parameters.description: The filename of the 3D model you want to see (with or without .ply extension). You can get a list of files from the [list models endpoint](#operation/ListModels)

get.description: This endpoint is used to download a specific 3D model as point cloud. The scan has not been transformed or processed in any way and the model is stored in binary PLY file format, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PLY_(file_format)

parameters.name: file
parameters.description: The filename of the 3D model you want to download (with or without .ply extension). You can get a list of files from the [list models endpoint](#operation/ListModels)

get.description: This endpoint is used to download a specific 3D model as point cloud. The scan has been rotated, stretched, skewed and put in the correct coordinate system according to the [block settings for its block ID](#operation/SettingsBlocksPath). The model is stored in binary PLY file format, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PLY_(file_format)

parameters.name: file
parameters.description: The filename of the 3D model you want to download (with or without .ply extension). You can get a list of files from the [list models endpoint](#operation/ListModels)

get.description: List services currently running on the system

Example.value:
[ + ]  chrony
[ - ]  console-setup.sh
[ + ]  cron
[ + ]  dbus
[ - ]  hwclock.sh
[ + ]  incron
[ - ]  keyboard-setup.sh
[ + ]  kmod
[ + ]  lighttpd
[ + ]  networking
[ + ]  procps
[ - ]  rsync
[ + ]  rsyslog
[ + ]  ssh
[ - ]  sudo
[ + ]  udev
[ + ]  ueyeethdrc
[ + ]  ueyeusbdrc

get.description: Returns the status of a particular service. Identical to the [status call below](#operation/ServicesStatus).

parameters.name: service
parameters.description:
The specific service you want to query.
Allowed services are any of the following:
- `scanner` or `f500`
- `webserver`
- `lighttpd`
- `chrony`
- `cron`
- `incron`

Example.value:
f500.service - F500 scanner

get.description: Returns the status of a particular service. Output is taken from systemd.

parameters.name: service
parameters.description:
The specific service you want to query.
Allowed services are any of the following:
- `scanner` or `f500`
- `webserver`
- `lighttpd`
- `chrony`
- `cron`
- `incron`

Example.value:
f500.service - F500 scanner
Loaded: loaded (/etc/systemd/system/f500.service; enabled; vendor preset: enabled)
Active: inactive (dead) since Wed 2019-11-27 08:47:13 UTC; 4h 50min ago

post.description: Tells systemd to start a specific service. Return value might be empty.

parameters.name: service
parameters.description:
The specific service you want to start.
Allowed services are any of the following:
- `scanner` or `f500`
- `webserver`
- `lighttpd`
- `chrony`
- `cron`
- `incron`

post.description: Tells systemd to stop a specific service. Return value might be empty.

parameters.name: service
parameters.description:
The specific service you want to stop.
Allowed services are any of the following:
- `scanner` or `f500`
- `webserver`
- `lighttpd`
- `chrony`
- `cron`
- `incron`

post.description: Tells systemd to restart a specific service. Return value might be empty.

parameters.name: service
parameters.description:
The specific service you want to restart.
Allowed services are any of the following:
- `scanner` or `f500`
- `webserver`
- `lighttpd`
- `chrony`
- `cron`
- `incron`

get.description:
Shows a webpage with several images used in the creation of one 3D profile. These can be used for troubleshooting in case of reflection artifacts.
Note: These are purely for debugging purposes and should not be treated as a feature.

Returns a specific debug image.
Note: These are purely for debugging purposes and should not be treated as a feature.

parameters.name: image
parameters.description:
Filename corresponding to a debug image. Possible values are
- `3d_ref0.bmp`: Previous reference image
- `3d_laser.bmp`: Image with laser line
- `3d_ref.bmp`: Current reference image
- `3d_laser_proc.bmp`: Difference of laser line and reference images
- `ms_0.bmp` ... `ms_9.bmp`: Debug images for multispectral camera

post.description:
Sends a request to the scanning process to store debug images during the next profile creation. Then waits for 50ms and returns a Refresh Content HTTP status.
Note: These are purely for debugging purposes and should not be treated as a feature.

get.description: Returns whether the system is 32bit or 64bit (returns system architecture string in every other case)
Dumps camera information and driver version
Returns a pretty printed string of the used operating system
Returns available space on the home partition

get.description: Returns the software version of the webserver. In case of a software update that only affects other parts of the scanner this version will not change.
